Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2014 09:09AM Cuetang wrote: coop-- another 30 something here telling you that you will kick this in the rear end!  You'll feel more in control after you start your treatments/have surgery, etc.  As you can tell, there's plenty of different forums where folks will give you answers from their experiences.  Aside from the Young with Breast Cancer forum, there's also boards on Young Survival Coalition (community.youngsurvival.org) that has a ton of information.  Between the BCO ladies and the YSC gals, I managed to keep my sanity through all of this cancer crap.  (HUGS)
Posts.Title: IDC Coopdizzle Kalonis52

Posts.Content: May 30, 2014 06:53AM Cuetang wrote: txranchmom--  sorry you had to join us and now have to have a crash course in all the terminology, and decisions that have to be made.  You've been given great advice so far by the ladies here, and unfortunately with this cancer business, none of us can truly tell you exactly what your prognosis is.  You will feel better once you get a plan in place.  When I was first diagnosed, I freaked because it was 1 week before I could see the first breast surgeon and another 1+ week before I saw a second breast surgeon, and ultimately 2 months before I had surgery (I'm a firm believer of second opinions, particularly something like this).  I was glad I did get a second opinion, because I went with the second breast surgeon (who was very detailed, and made me do things like an MRI, etc.).    As for your question on lumpectomy, you'll eventually come to that decision when you learn a bit more about the details of the cancer, and what you are comfortable with.  The thread farmerlucy provided has some great ladies in there.  I've also used the Young Survival Coalition's (YSC) forums too to seek advice (I'm the same age as you).  There's also a thread with a lot of ladies from Texas that may be able to provide recommendations as to doctors for you as well: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/6/topic/8... .  There will be someone on these various threads on BCO that will be able to share their experiences with any questions you have throughout this process.  HUGS.

My breast surgeon required an MRI before I even saw him, so he could have a better idea of what was going on in my breasts and to see if there were any possible lymph nodes involved. I had a bilateral mastectomy and DIEP flap surgery last month and my plastic surgeon had me do a CT angiogram to map out the blood vessels in my chest/tummy area (but not all plastic surgeons may take this step).

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2013 06:07PM - edited Mar 25, 2013 06:09PM by Cuetang You have to live the results, not your surgeon. Two surgeons I saw were suggesting I do the lumpectomy versus a mastectomy. I ended up choosing a bilateral mastectomy. Both were willing to do it and respected my decision. You should stick with the surgeon only if you feel comfortable with them. My hubby didn't like my PS's attitude but I stuck with him because I knew he did excellent work based off discussions with his previous patients. Any time for a second opinion with another surgeon just for the heck of it?

My DH had to tell me to stop making that pained anticipation face, that it was already out (I had my eyes closed for all of the removals). Hopefully the next ones will be a piece of cake for you and painless!

It's definitely important to not rush things to avoid complications. Unfortunately everyone differs on how long the drains are in for.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 11:21AM Cuetang wrote: SonjaJ -- like Janet456 said, doctors vary in their policies.  My friend's doctor refused to discuss results over the phone after she found a lump and her results were benign (she was mad that she had to go in and go through all the emotions of thinking the worse possible outcome).  Meanwhile, mine told me over the phone that I had cancer.  Don't think the worse just because you have to go in (I know it's HARD!).  Hang in there!  (hugs)
Posts.Title: This is torture SonjaJ sharon1953-

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 10:31PM Cuetang wrote: Oh boooooo! :( Sorry you had to join our group, but you will find a bunch of great resources at BCO. There is a thread under IDC called 2013 Sister Warriors that include a bunch of us that were diagnosed this year. Feel free to hop on there if you want to chat and see how we have gone through things or bounce ideas off each other. Make sure you get a copy of all your pathology reports and film copies of your mammogram and copies of your ultrasound when you go see the breast surgeon. Like others have said, don't be afraid to get second opinions. I was glad I got a second opinion because that was the breast surgeon I ended up using instead. Hang in there and unfortunately there are plenty of women here that have gone through this road already, but can offer guidance and knowledge of their experiences.
Posts.Title: This is torture SonjaJ sharon1953-

Posts.Content: May 21, 2013 02:19PM - edited May 21, 2013 02:24PM by Cuetang Adowney76-- sorry you had to join this group, but glad you found BCO. You're probably going through one of the worse parts of it now. I was diagnosed this January at age 33 and read a lot of things about cancers being more aggressive in younger women, yadda yadda. Bottom line is that there are so many factors that play into whether you will have chemo or not (i.e. type of tumor such as the triple negative that is more receptive to chemo, aggressiveness of the tumor, size, lymph node involvement, lymphatic invasion, etc.) and that would be the oncologist's call. How big was your tumor? Do you know the hormone receptors of your tumor (ER PR Her-2)? I'm one example of someone that got two medical oncologist opinions and a radiological oncologist opinion and did not end up with chemo or radiation. Don't hesitate to see a second opinion with another surgeon. While cancer is urgent, it can wait for another opinion as well. I actually was happier with my second opinion doctor, who made me do things like get an MRI, talk to plastic surgeons about reconstruction options, and an oncologist. I wasn't part of an NCI cancer center, but essentially my breast surgeon built that similar team around me. Mentally, I'm not going to lie, this won't be easy. However, you'll find out that you are so much stronger than you ever thought you were in this process. Don't hesitate to lean on family and friends during this time and if they offer help, take it. There also a group, Young Survival Coalition (YSC) that has their boards and meet ups for those under 40 diagnosed with BC (I just went to a happy hour yesterday). Additionally, feel free to join in the IDC forum, "2013 Sister Warriors", which includes us diagnosed this year with IDC. You'll see all different favors of treatments that we've gone through with our respective cancers.
Posts.Title: 36 and just diagnosed...are you kidding me? adowney76 tlew

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2013 07:52PM Cuetang wrote: Sharon1953-- sorry that you too had to join us. As I posted earlier, you are welcome to join our thread under IDC, 2013 sister warriors. This is a real "hurry up and wait" thing, and I agree it's nerve wracking and frustrating. You are truly in one of the worse parts of BC, right after diagnosis, and before a treatment plan is set. For me, all I had was the ultrasound and MRI and the typical blood tests before any operation. Unless an oncologist or the breast surgeon recommends actions such as neo adjuvant chemotherapy, you probably won't know your final treatment plan until the surgery pathology results come back. That's where I am now. My oncologist was waiting for my surgery pathology and Oncotype results first. If you are going for a mastectomy, meeting with the plastic surgeon is a great thing because you will find out all the reconstruction options. After you have decided that, then the two surgeon offices can coordinate their times for a surgery date. Also don't be afraid to ask for second opinions during this process as well. Kayezzy66-- your husband did a great thing there. :). Tell him to keep finding distractions for you! Remember, it isn't cancer unless the report tells you it is. Hard to be calm I definitely know, but keep those distractions going so you can enjoy the weekend. B9 thoughts sent your way!!
Posts.Title: This is torture SonjaJ sharon1953-

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 08:35PM Cuetang wrote: tb2005 -- it's difficult especially around our age (I'm 34) with some of these decisions.  Like Ziggy had pointed out already, for example, do you have kids already?  If you plan on having kids later-- is the desire to breastfeed something that is really important to you?  How attached are you to your breasts?  It's a hard decision for most of us to have to make and all this cancer stuff just sucks.  Have you had an opportunity to consult with a plastic surgeon?  It's completely reasonable to going back and forth with these decisions.  Also, have you had any genetic testing done (or is that standard at all in Australia)?  Any results from genetic testing could also tell you if you are predisposed to breast cancer and that could play into your final decision as well. In my case, I am a worrywart and I knew that the bilateral mastectomy was the way I wanted to go.  I wasn't strongly for or against breastfeeding and figured if I lost sensation in one side, the other side wouldn't matter as much.  Also, I chose the DIEP reconstruction (which could only be done once), so I might as well have strived for symmetry at the same time. Whatever you decide, there's no right or wrong.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Don't know what to do, any advice? tb2005 del4

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 05:25AM Cuetang wrote: Waiting for test results totally suck suck suck.  I had a ki-67 of 25% (lower than yours but still considered "high") and pinned my MO down to get me some answers.  I was expecting a high Oncotype score, but mine's ended up being an "8".  My MO and a second-opinion MO (I saw two...after all, I wanted to make sure whatever my treatment plan would be would be the best one for me) -- both said that the ki-67 could be unreliable at times and that it was only one piece of information but not the determining factor that would decide what they would do.  I even got the MO to go to the pathologist and the tumor board a second time before I would accept my final treatment plan.  Whatever it is for you, good luck!
Posts.Title: Waiting for OncoType LovebeingNana noonrider

Posts.Content: Cuetang wrote: Like everyone here, I figured I'd post a little bit about myself.  I had a core needle biopsy earlier this month, that revealed IDC and DCIS, about 1.5cm.  I got the bad news on 1/11/13.  Since the core needle biopsy, I haven't been able to sleep more than 4-5 hours at a time and my brain is constantly thinking about this over and over again.  I've made myself even more anxious thinking about random medical ailments I had last year (i.e. two episodes of shortness of breath and coughing that I had previously chalked up to really bad acid reflux) and wondered if that was BC related.  I've met with one breast surgeon and will get another opinion this week, then hopefully will move onto my treatment plan.  The first one saw the breast MRI I had and seemed optimistic because there wasn't any sign of node involvement.  However, I've read here that there are plenty of ladies that ended up having node involvement after a SNB. I'm hoping for at least a MX with immediate DIEP reconstruction at this point, but realize that the ladies here have taken a lot of different routes.  I'm more than a little freaked out because I thought I was young and invincible previously, being 33 years old. My husband and I had planned on two vacations and starting a family this year, but those plans have gone out the door for now.  The just not knowing, the endless possibilities of what it "could be" as well as other factors, such as fertility have really fed into my emotional roller coaster.  I've never been prone to anxiety attacks or "freak out" sessions, but BC has certainly changed that as well.  I took my first Ambien last night, but that provided only about 5 hours of straight sleep, and it's certainly something I do not wish to be dependant upon.  My husband also says that I will take down the internet with all of my reading... When will good sleep that I had before the BC diagnosis come back?  Will it ever? Diagnosed at age 33. Dx 1/11/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 3/7/2013 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Dx 3/8/2013, DCIS, <1cm, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 6/23/2013 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Hormonal Therapy Hormonal Therapy Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: When does uninterrupted sleep come back and anxiety decrease? Cuetang Alicethecat

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2013 03:05AM Cuetang wrote: Dmarie24-- you're in one of the hardest times right now, with all the information getting thrown at you yet not having all the puzzle pieces together. The choice for the lumpectomy versus the mastectomy is a difficult one. Some women are really attached and think they are mutilating themselves with a mastectomy. Others just want the darn breasts gone. I fell into the latter category because I knew I would have major anxiety issues going through the what-ifs scenario in the future. I had a nipple and skin sparing bilateral mastectomy with immediate DIEP reconstruction in March. Because my reconstruction used my own tummy tissue, I woke up to breasts that looked like my own, just shaped slightly differently. Good luck with your final decision and keep that chin up! :)

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2013 06:27PM Cuetang wrote: Hi Ladies!  Well the verdict is in for me.  The tumor board came to the consensus that I will not be having chemo.  They looked at my slides during their conference and believe that it is a slow growing tumor and an Oncotype score of 8 supported that, despite showing a high ki-67 score of 25%.  I narrowly missed rads (because of a super duper close skin margin) and now I missed chemo.  Am I fully comfortable with this?  Not reallly.  However, I guess I have to put my faith with the doctors.  I'm also getting recommended for ovarian suppression, but won't know what it is until my next appointment with the oncologist.  Hellloooo hot flashes and bone issues at 33!  tparksprof -- hurray for the removal of the pesky drains!!  Keep fighting and hold that chin up despite all the crap that has been sent your way.  Have a great weekend.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 10:48PM - edited Apr 10, 2013 10:50PM by Cuetang AryaS-- I'm sorry you had to join us in this group, but glad you found us!  Unfortunately, I think you're at one of the worse parts of things, knowing that you have cancer but then you don't have a treatment plan yet.  You will get TONS of information thrown at you, yet, with each appointment you get more pieces to the puzzle.  As for the size difference between the ultrasound and the MRI, I think you said you didn't meet with your breast surgeon yet?  I think your breast surgeon will best be able to give you an answer to your question.  Keep in mind that the size differential could be due to a number of factors, so please don't google about that and leave it up to your medical team to tell you the reason for it.  I'm 33 right now, and am quickly learning that yes, for us younger ones, treatment plans may be more aggressive, but that doesn't necessarily guarantee you chemo these days, especially with tools such as the Oncotype test, but that would be up to how your medical oncologist handles things.  If it's the plastic surgeon that told you about the chemo, I would definitely defer to the oncologist.  You'll also find a thread in the IDC section, listed 2013 Sister Warriors.  There are those of us just diagnosed with IDC this year and are in various stages of surgery/treatment.  You can see what we've gone through as well as share stories, bounce ideas off one another, or get additional input.  Don't forget that you can always get second opinions of things.  This is going to be an emotional roller coaster, and you'e allowed to feel scared and vulnerable, but remember, you WILL get through this! Nicolegug --  good luck on your visits, and good for you for going for that second opinion!  The bilateral MRI will be alright, be prepared to hold that "superman" position for a bit of time!  Hang in there.  (hugs).
Posts.Title: Diagnosed last week AryaS dwill

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2014 10:33AM Cuetang wrote: Kelly--  sorry you had to join us here, and I hope you got some answers at your doctor's appointment.  Whatever it is, hair or no hair, you'll overcome it!  I was diagnosed at the same age as you last year...and I can't say that it has been easy, but all of us here can hopefully share our experiences and answer any questions you may have along your road to kicking BC to the curb.  There's a forum here at BCO with a thread of ladies in their 30s that you can check out, along with the Young Survival Coalition (YSC) ladies community forums as well.  Whatever the news it, HUGS!

YSC has a large group of ladies in the Washington, DC area that meet monthly for happy hour, if you're up for speaking with others about breast cancer and their experiences. Of course, the rest of us are here on the various threads/boards to help provide advice and our experiences through the process. BC is the crappiest emotional roller coaster to be on, so hang in there, and we are all here for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 12:23PM Cuetang wrote: The breast cancer emotional rollercoaster really stinks. Unfortunately, it seems that that it is a continual one that happens over and over again through diagnosis, surgery, chemo, scans, check ups. We are all stronger than we think, hang in there everyone, especially through the sucky days. Good luck to those having surgery coming up....the anticipation was worse than the actual surgery I think. I had my first PS post op appointment today and got 3 of 4 drains pulled (yippee!). However, I know after my oncologist appointment and treatment plan coming up, there will be good and bad days and am glad for all of one here sharing their experiences and understanding how awful of a roller coaster ride we are all on now. Hugs to everyone and happy Friday!

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2013 01:10PM Cuetang wrote: Yay mamsixtaz!  Glad to hear of your updates and relax and heal.  I kept myself amused at the hospital by listening to nurses complain about other patients (I got a room right next to the nurses station) and of one patient who snuck a cupcake when she wasn't supposed to have any. Kap-- yay for drain removal!  I have to admit, I was kind of bad.  I couldn't get an appointment with my PS until next Wednesday, but had an appointment with the BS today so I convinced my BS to remove my last drain for me. txanne -- you are my hero on being back at work today!  Ironmagnolia -- thanks for posting about the "zings".  I have these "zings" that feel like someone is like putting an electric shock to me (only on one side).  Was freaking out until I saw your post. TinaHoff--everything pretty much stinks in this whole BC journey.  I made myself feel better by thinking that having my bilateral mastectomy was a move forward in getting me cancer free.  Hang in there! LKSHER-- great news on the PET scan! Don't you feel like that you have a whole pharmacy at home?  Hopefully the good news on the scan and the call with the nurse made you feel more comfortable and that you're able to get some rest with less worry.
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2013 05:04PM Cuetang wrote: Thanks Linda! i only did the sentinel nodes, and I can get up to almost 180 degrees, but reaching behind me seems to be the challenge. Congrats gardengirl on the drain removed! As for laying flat, I gradually removed pillows after surgery so I could see where my comfort level was.
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2013 10:15PM Cuetang wrote: ironmagnolia and pattysmiles -- oh what a roller coaster this BC ride is.  I too didn't get a "clean margin" (didn't think that was possible with a BMX!), but my BS recognized that during surgery and in his words "scraped everything there" and in their weekly peer meeting, the radiological oncologist also concurred that radiation was not recommended at this time (whew).  I'm meeting with the RO based off of a recommendation by the BS -- the BS thinks I should talk to the RO so I have a clearer understanding of how they came to the conclusion of not recommending rads (I had less than a 1mm margin according to my path report). Pattysmiles -- it might be good to check and see if your health insurance will cover the oncotype.  I was fortunate enough to deal with my health insurance's nurse navigator assigned to me and she clearly outlined the conditions that an oncotype would be covered in my case.  For me, I have an Aetna HMO and they won't pay for it if I have any positive nodes since that to them would mean chemo for me.  The oncotype company called and said that I will have results 7-10 days after they receive the "specimen".  I'm so with you ....this "hurry up and wait" mode royally sucks!  2girls-2spaniels -- great news!
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 12:44AM - edited Mar 29, 2013 12:48AM by Cuetang Tparksprof-- Sorry you couldn't get the drains out, hopefully soon! Glad to hear that there's little pain. Listen to your body and rest up. :) Gma04-- you are most certainly welcome to join our group as well even though your surgery date was February. Glad you found us on BCO. Our March sisters are a wonderful group of gals who I'm sure someone will chime in with regards to your question. For me, I had 4 drains, 3 removed 7 days after surgery and the last one around 2 weeks. Hopefully you can get them out soon so you can feel better and not have those annoying buggers to deal with! Are you draining a lot over 30ccs consistently? Also, have you been very active with the drains? I heard you get more output if you're trying to do a lot... I kinda turned into lazy couch potato for the two weeks. :)
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 11:59PM Cuetang wrote: Hello March surgery sisters, I love reading all the updates and sounds like we are all well on our ways for healing, and yes, some bumps and bruises along the way as well. I can't believe I'm a month out from surgery. I don't have a full range of motion yet, but then again, did anyone provide a timeline of when you are supposed to have full ROM back after a mastectomy? I was told to set up PT appointments if I had issues...but I haven't done it yet because I didn't see this as much of an "issue"... Maureen-- you totally rock in keeping updated with all of us and working too! Yep, I've been active on the other boards as I try to be patient in my "waiting" mode to hear what my oncologist and second opinion oncologist have to say about my treatment plan next week. I have an Oncotype score of 8, so expect to hear possibly no chemo but am scared that I am not throwing everything I can at the beast if that's the case. Ok, I'm rambling.... Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2013 06:02PM Cuetang wrote: Like Maureen has said, I too could wish we could fast forward the days before surgery and all the anxiety associated with it. Hang in there, you will feel so much better after surgery (I know, so weird right considering they are big surgeries and all). 9 days post op, I'm in a better place than the days before surgery (despite all the surgery incisions and the pesky last drain). Mamasixtaz-- I had the DIEP flap surgery and ended up being at least 12 hours. Hilarious part of things was that they stuck a big butt cushion on my rear end to account for the long surgery time. I was also told 4-5 days in the hospital but ended up staying 3. Sounds like you have a great support system and you'll totally rock the surgery! :) Shari-- You're definitely not being silly, BC really messes with all of our minds. We just have to know that we did all the research that we could do and gave the cancer all we had. After surgery, you'll feel so much better, for sure!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2013 01:24PM Cuetang wrote: Question for the ladies that had mastectomies -- do any of you have any odd night sweats? I find that I wake up now in the mornings more than a little sweaty (my heater is set at my normal temperature) and I don't ever remember this happening before my surgery. I've been combing the boards and see some women report some night sweats after their mastectomy. I'm not having hot flashes and nowhere near being menopausal yet. Just curious....just find it kinda meh to feel sticky every morning I wake up....
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2013 12:43PM - edited Mar 26, 2013 12:45PM by Cuetang Thanks ladies for the input on the night sweats!  I haven't started any treatment plans or chemo, and I'm 33, so having night sweats all of a sudden was really making me wonder about things.  It really must be the trauma of having such a huge surgery that my body doesn't like even though I *so far* have been feeling pretty decent.  Isn't it amazing how we don't think about things like a nice shower or a hair wash the way we do until after our surgeries?  Maureen -- you mom is definitely your angel and with you every step of the way.  I'm glad you have such great memories that you can smile upon with her. Thankful2day -- you'll feel awesome after your drains get pulled today!  I had a weird day about 4 days after my surgery where one drain was consistently doing about 12 a day, then that one day it did 50!  I was so worried, but thank goodness I didn't see my PS until 2 days later, where it went back down to about 8-10 each day for 2 days.  He thought something may have been stuck and just "unstuck" that day, resulting in the high number. LKSHER-- I agree with about the fear of mets.  It is like a "cancer radio" where you can tone it down but never really turn it off.  In time, we will all learn our own ways on how to tune things out for a while, some of us better than others.  I'm one of those that is still trying to figure out ways on trying not to overanalyze my body (so hard!), but hopefully as others have said, as time goes on that radio will be quieter and blend in with the rest of the noises in the background.  Foreverchanged72612-- good news that you only had to do the SNB and no surprises!  *happy dance*  Best wishes to the rest of the March surgery sisters!!
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 09:01PM Cuetang wrote: Gardengirl-- I feel ya there about the stupid drains! That's why I somehow convinced my BS to remove my last one instead of waiting for my overbooked PS another week later. Good idea to let the girls free to help relieve some of the pain. Ssla01-- great news! :)
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2013 09:33PM Cuetang wrote: TinaHoff-- thanks for the update!  I didn't feel too hot the first week after surgery.  You've just completed surgery, give yourself time to feel better.  It'll be even better when the drains go away! Jrose14 and kap -- I was lucky to not experience it this time around (probably because I can't feel anything lol), but when I had my thyroidectomy in the fall, I couldn't stand ANYTHING touching the incision line or the skin around it.  It's the nerves going wacky, and it's super duper annoying.  At some point, hopefully it goes away!  I don't have full range of motion either kap, but am trying to do my exercises that the doctor and the PT (which I saw before surgery only) recommended.  Hopefully it gets better soon.  If not, I'm thinking about booking some PT sessions.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 09:23AM Cuetang wrote: Hi ladies!  Joining this thread...I will be having a bilateral MX with immediate DIEP reconstruction on March 8.  I was diagnosed in early January, but it took a while to get through all the doctor visits, dealing with insurance, and getting on both the BS and PS's calendar.  Am a bit nervous because like butterflylady2012, I just want the darn cancer out of me!  No treatment plan yet until after the surgery.  I'll start shopping for supplies this weekend....planning for the recovery period has begun!

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2013 10:38PM - edited Mar 3, 2013 10:38PM by Cuetang Ironmagnolia -- it's amazing how different surgeons do different things. I was told I'd be in the hospital for 3-4 days, but my PS won't use a pain ball (eek?). He said catheter for a day, two at most and that he's ok with shower in the hospital and at home even with the drains. Either way it all sounds so bleeeh, doesn't it? Just can wait to fast forward until next month, when we are all mostly "healed" from surgeries! :) Maureen-- best wishes for your surgery as well tomorrow! Get some rest ladies if you can.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2013 08:28PM Cuetang wrote: Vegannicole--so glad you found an oncologist that you liked!  Sorry you feel crummy...but yes, think positive!    Lou4of7 -- great update and wowzer in walking 2 miles today so soon after your surgery.  great job!  sending happy healing thoughts your way.
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2013 09:24PM Cuetang wrote: Rebex -- it's so interesting that if you look at our stats, it almost looks exactly the same, but our oncologists are totally leaning in opposite directions.  My oncologist is leaning towards tamoxifen only, but it was my high ki-67 that made her look at things again.  I think earliest tomorrow for news, but probably early next week. I just want to move forward!  Were you able to get a date for your Oncotype results?  I called my doctor's office the day that Genomics said they would send in the results and the nurse navigator was able to tell me right away what my score was.   A second oncologist I saw for that second opinion said that if she offered me chemo, it would be medical malpractice.  This is all so confusing.  Deciding on having a bilateral MX and the type of reconstruction was way easier than this!
Posts.Title: March 2013 Surgeries kap Maureen1

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 04:21PM Cuetang wrote: pattij--  you are definitely not alone, and it sucks that you've having another go-around with this stupid BC crap.  We're all here to listen.  We have all been in that deep dark hole before, but just remember you can't let this @#$% take any more from you than it already has.  For me, I finally understood those depression commercials you see where there's that cloud hanging over your head and it took a good long time for me to shake it off and learn to live my life happy again.  One step at a time, and you will beat this thing.  (MORE HUGS)!
